PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. F.H. Olmstead (was Milly Parley)
Address: Gregg, Manitoba (of Moffat, Sask.)
Birthplace: Wolseley, Assiniboia (now Sask.)

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? (I remember helping my mother in the kitchen in 1897.)
Where did you set up housekeeping? (Started assisting my brothers in 1897.)
Where had you been living before that? (The oldest girl in the family.)
For how many people did you prepare meals? (8, on a farm.)
How far was it to your nearest store? (14 miles.)
How often could a visit be made to the store? (Once a month or oftener.)
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? (We could buy any groceries we wanted at the store but prices were high so we could only get trade [no cash] for our butter & eggs. We usually traded a pig for the bill at the end of the year.)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (Grist mill, got our own wheat ground into flour. Later on, we got back to the old-fashioned flour.)
In what quantities did you buy it? (Pounds.)
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? (3 to 5 dollars.)
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? (20 miles, what year? 1908.)
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? (2.)
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? (Yes.)
How did you grind it? (With a hammer until we got a coffee mill. We had an electric grinder after 1908 and were able to grind our own wheat as well as crushing chaff for the stock.)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We kept our own cows. Other herd $2.00.

Butter? Freshly made. Eggs? From our own hens.

What was the price of butter? $2.00.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Hand made cheese pressed in brick.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? In summer we got wild game, also had our own meat salted down.

How did you get fresh meat? In winter we got wild game. Also killed beef & pork which we kept frozen.

How often did you get fresh meat? Twice a week in town but we believed in getting 90% from living off the farm.

How did you preserve meat? We started making canned meat about 1914.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? About 1917.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, prairie chicken, as well as tame fowl.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? We bought salted fresh for a change - sometimes red herring.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & canned both on.

Kind's? Salmon in cans, about 1906.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) A. Well. (We were 1 mile from a good spring.)

How far was this water from your home? Our best well was 1/4 mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made our own, also bought.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Good soaps?

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Columbian, etc.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Off our own farm.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had a wood box heater in the early days. Got coal heaters about 1902 & a boiler burner in 1914 & a furnace in 1925. Still using coal, & plenty of wood in use too.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**October 1889**

- **Breakfast:** Porridge, ham & eggs - Juice - Toast & tea or milk
- **Dinner:** Soup - Meat & vegetables - Rolls - Jelly - Pudding - Biscuits & tea or milk
- **Supper:** Meat pie, potatoes

---

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

*1859*... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I can remember this meal. Mr. and Mrs. Lee & their 3 little children drove over in a covered sleigh also a bachelor neighbor was present. There were 11 at the table. We had turkey & plum pudding—a real Scotch meal. Mother had out her silver tea pot & flatware & china dishes. Not much different from Christmas meals nowadays.

---

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never. We were careful & what we had & saved up for the next year.
Give a typical day's menu (great family dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list those things which they grew in the yard, things they bought at the store, etc.

Breakfast - Porridge, from 1887

Dinner - Soup, meat, potatoes, roast beef, pie, vegetables, some sea salted pork, jam, milk

Supper - 1889

The next year, give your first Christmas dinner in the same way.

What we had & how much it cost.

We were careful & what we had & how much it cost.

The next year.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Everything is more convenient than it used to be.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still try to get about 90% of our living from the farm.
